Perhaps ask about the size and types of apps?   Someone running a simple single-server app has different needs than someone running dozens of app servers with multiple Catalyst apps to make up a single site -- with dozens of developers, like we are.

I'd like to see more "Best Practices", and in my case especially about scaling, which although is not specifically related to Catalyst, helps to think about early on.   People have different needs, but there's often hope of sites growing and need to know that growth can and will be supported.

More focus on Models -- from my experience developers tend to not grasp the concept of using Models to interface with Catalyst and instead use the Controllers for business logic.    Seems common on the list that for new users Catalyst IS the application instead of more of a dispatching layer.

Main reason I'm shifting away from Catalyst is that I think it's quite resource hungry, compared to Mojolicious. Installation of all the dependencies takes quite some time, even without running the tests. The model system is a bit, hmm. It's cool how Catalyst can instantiate them from the config file, but it's a pain when you need the models in some other script without starting the entire Catalyst app. I guess Bread::Board could solve this nicely, but also think that's a bit too much.

But all in all I'm quite happy with it and enjoy supporting/developing my current Catalyst webapps.

Past:
I came to perl in mid-2006, and began to learn web dev few months later. First CGI, then Mason, the someone pointed me to Catalyst. Which I use and love ever since. 

Present:
In the past my app's logic was all in the controllers, latter some business logic moved into DBIC result(set) classes, today its all in $c->model('App') (from the Catalyst point of view), with few controllers.... what I mean is.. wouldn't be too hard to move away from Catalyst... specially when I'm looking forward to some features (like non-blocking baked into core)... I just don't move away coz I love Catalyst! I love the #catalyst channel always helped me! Please guys, don't drift away!!!

Future:
IMHO, I see too much effort to maintain backwards compat, and I think there should be a limit to the backward compatibility commitment. 

I'd love to see Catalyst 6.0, rethought to be the web app framework for the apps of the future!! 
Lets bake it with Bread::Board... with non-blocking features in the core... more PSGI integrated ... and all the features you guys couldnt implement in the 5.x era ... even if that costs backward compatibility. A new beginning.... thats what 2012 is supposed to be!

When I did a google search for "catalyst roadmap" it gave me this page. http://wiki.catalystframework.org/wiki/roadmap -- Which has a last modified of 2009. 

I think catalyst should continue to move forward. I think that breaking some backwards compatibility at the version 6 mark could be good. An example would be to stop supporting certain older versions of Perl, and deprecated configuration options at that point.

Most of my pain points with Catalyst deal with Plugin's or extensions. I want to do common action X ( like requireSSL ). The plugin module kinda works. My boss won't pay me to rewrite it. So I end up having to code or configure around it's quirks. Having some place (forum or SO like, not IRC ) to talk about these kind of issues besides their CPAN page would be useful. I could see it being a way to get people to pickup orphaned packages, or build alternatives.

I usually only join the IRC channel when I have a question, and I leave it shortly after. At one point in my life I used to idle in IRC all the time. Now, I only connect when I need info. Most of the kids I meet at College don't even know what IRC is. 
I guess what I am saying is we can pickup more people by bringing the community to them. Forums, Facebook Pages, and Google+ Hangouts are more popular to the younger generation. 

I'll do my best to be on IRC for the town hall meeting.

Overall, Catalyst has served me very well from the first clumsy app I wrote years ago on the Catalyst 5.8 stack to the current 5.9x releases with PSGI running behind the scenes.  The features continue to improve, and the ease with which I can take advantage of new or more complicated technologies from within the Catalyst ecosystem is impressive.

However, the one thing I have always struggled with in Catalyst (more so than Perl in general) is the amount of outdated, poor, of just missing information scattered around.  In many cases (blogs and tutorials), there is no indication of which Catalyst version is being used, which means the code shown could range from deprecated practices to just plain doesn't work.  In other cases, certain modules or features are painfully under-documented.

The official Catalyst site could do a lot to help the situation but it often seems to lag behind on the latest information, or only parts of the site are kept up to date.  Even now, there are some broken links or wiki pages that could certainly use a refresh.  It also gives the impression that the Catalyst project or the general ecosystem is not as alive and vibrant as I believe it really is.

I don't want to end on a criticism, so I'll finish up by saying that for me personally (a Perl enthusiast and recreational programmer for the last decade), Catalyst has done more to extend my knowledge of an interest in doing projects with Perl than anything else.  The fight to find the right guidance online can be frustrating at times, but the benefits and knowledge I have gained from making Catalyst my go-to tool for building websites certainly make it all worth it in the end.

column18:
Catalyst was my choice when it was the only widespread choice of MVC for Perl, though it never appealed to me.

Even basic stuff, like a rest service, required an extra module and forced me to use subroutines like "sub thing_GET", which I find to be very aesthetically unpleasing.  Chaining seems like a good idea, but I found them to be hard to manage due to a lack of a central reference of routes.  It could have been my n00bness, but I found the command line route reporting to be inaccurate at times.   Not to mention my initial usage of detach, which I've discovered is pure evil in terms of long-term maintenance and transparency.

The dependency chain is also something that I found very cumbersome.  Sometimes, I wanted to quickly deploy to a platform in order to test something out, but the large dep chain deters quick-anything.  I found it to negate the spirit of TDD and fast iterations.

The other problem I had with the framework is that there seemed to be a distinct lack of effort into making it feel fresh and new.  At the time, the wiki was chaotic, and the main documentation, being limited to the graphical presentation of search.cpan.org, seemed tired.

To be honest, after a couple production deployments of Catalyst sites, I was about to give up on Perl completely; it seemed like my views on development were not compatible with the Perl community as a whole.  The appearance of some other Frameworks circa 2009 kept me sticking around.

-

I don't intend to be negative, but the reason for polls is feedback, so I'm giving you my entire impression.  Hope it helps :)

I hope this doesn't sound like griping.  I work on a bunch of stuff which makes a lot of use out of Catalyst and it's what I do every day at $work.  So, my career and my pet projects owe a lot to the Catalyst team.  :)

For me personally, I really like what Catalyst can do, but it seems like a bit of a black box to me most of the time.  I first started with CGI::Application for a framework. Coming from that background, once I started playing with Catalyst, it took me a long time to wrap my head around how it works.  I do lots of work with it now, so I have a basic handle on how things work.

What would help a lot, I think is documenting a lot of the stuff that seems to be obvious to the people on IRC but which isn't obvious to the rest of the world.  Stuff like a list of best practices, plugins to use, plugins to avoid, how to best set up your models etc so that you can easily access the stuff you need when running a cron as well as inside the application.

Also, if there were some sample apps on Github which you could easily to deploy to demonstrate best practices, I think that would be great.  If these exist and I don't know about them, I apologize.  I work on MetaCPAN (which is one example of a Catalyst app on Github) but before this I wasn't aware of other real, useful apps you could easily get the source code for.

I've played a bit with Dancer and, because of its simplicity, it was much, much easier for me to get up and running with it than with Catalyst.  I also really like how with Dancer you can easily designate routes for GET vs POST right out of the box.  It makes it so simple to get started with.  Doing the same kind of thing with Catalyst::Action::REST isn't nearly as easy.  So, my inclination at this point is to use Dancer for easy (or RESTish) stuff that I need to get up and running quickly and to use Catalyst for stuff that needs access to a lot of plugins.

Lastly, at this point, it kind of feels easier to contribute to projects which are on Github.  I realize not everyone feels that way, but I do feel like keeping development on Github at this point probably makes it easier for some people to contribute.  Sending a pull request feels a lot easier than asking for a commit bit.

Firstly, encouragement. You've done a great job and it is very much appreciated. It very impressive, fast and flexible system.

A few things: The biggest issue is CPAN and the perl module system. There needs to be a really simple way of loading everything up for dev and to deploy to prod as (perhaps) a single command. I'm aware of attempts being made, but they are always let down by the perl module testing problems. I can pretty well bet that something will go wrong to prevent an automated install, almost always involving testing phase of cpan installation. Cpan modules are both perl's greatest strength but also its Achilles heal. For example, the mojolicious wiki app should be a great reusable resource, but it has a vast set of dependencies that are too visible for a deployment (c.f. linked java or C object code). Can we fix this with par or a compiler approach? Even just an archive of modules? Or is our problem the one java had, that we ought to be preferring pure-perl implementations as the external (system) dependencies are much reduced.

Secondly, You are completely right that now is a good time to look at overall direction. Things like dancer, mojolicous and node.js are showing easy ways of trying out techniques that will be important in the future, like socket.io and distributed DBs - essentially integrating a greater degree of autonomous event flow without getting to huge cpan frameworks.

Thirdly, as you will have noticed, there is a trend to JS based client side, which we need to support with socket.io, etc. There are many very interesting experiments which we should keep an eye on. In fact, it might be that we can't think of a good way to do this other than making it easy to drop into JS script code or cross calling node.js.

Fourthly, reusable applications that can be skinned and adapted would be great in CPAN, maybe as patterns. 

Fifthly, if you decided to make a big break in API/use for Catalyst 6 to support new ideas, just make sure that *calling* cat 5.x functions is bomb proof. Backward compatibility is much appreciated, but at some point I do understand that things have to change.

I don't like Catalyst because it makes it easy to hide the workings of a web site. For example, take the URL http://localhost:3000/foo/bar/baz. Imagine I need to make a change to the page that is shown at this address. I would start by looking for a 'sub baz' in a Foo/Bar.pm controller. It might not be there, because Foo.pm or Bar.pm have 'baz' in a Path attribute, so now I have to go hunting for that.

Another example is the stash, which is too easy to use as a global variable stash. My template uses 'somevar', and I need to find where it was set. Any of the methods in the controllers that were used in executing that URL have could have set it.

I would love the --debug output of *_server.pl to show me the execution path that is taken when a page request is made, even if it's just a list of controller methods that were called. "perl -d *_server.pl" is too unwieldy for this.

If there is a way to do any of that, and I just don't know about it, then I'd suggest adding it to the debugging section of the manual.

I've had only tangential involvement with Catalyst. (I don't follow the mailing list, web site, IRC, or releases.) Once managing a project where it was used, and in another case helping to evaluate it as a potential framework for a project. In the latter case, Dancer was chosen instead, despite a recommendation from myself and the developer I was working with for Catalyst, which we felt had better internal architecture and was a more proven project. (And we were pretty much proven correct in the course of the project, encountering bugs and architecture issues with Dancer.)

While there isn't much you can do about the practice in IT to go after the new and shiny thing, it does seem like there are opportunities to revise Catalyst to offer the same benefits as some of the newer tools. For example, move further in the direction of having a minimal core kernel, so that complexity and dependencies are minimized. Relegate everything else to plug-ins. (Our client was strongly influenced by Dancer's minimal dependent module count.) 

Package Catalyst so that it has a super easy "out of the box" experience, with template applications and a bundled web server. (Maybe you already do this? If so, publicize it.) Consider bundling new APIs layered on top of the Catalyst core that provide the Dancer-like syntax, that many seem to prefer. (Perhaps a plug-in already exists for this.)

Consider the marketing benefit to releasing such a bundle under a new name on CPAN. (Something new and shiny to pull in those who dismiss Catalyst as being the framework of 5 years ago.) It could be built from a standard Catalyst release using automation, so minimal additional maintenance overhead, and once you've brought a new developer into the fold, they'll be using something that is fully compatible with the greater Catalyst ecosystem.

column18:
The Catalyst Advent Calendar is a fantastic source of information but the information gets quickly outdated as the development process is running quite fast. The already published articles should be updated or marked as obsolete when it's known the proposed solution(s) no longer work.

The documentation is quite good but the learning curve is damn steep! Great there are already books (oh, did I mention outdated?) available.

And since it's Perl and TMTOWTDI the developers may get confused sometimes when they're choosing the "right one" framework to be used as DB backend, templating, forms, etc. There might be good to put some recommendations somewhere.

And one last thing -- there should be more focus put on i18n, l10n and UTF-8 support. At least, our app seems to handle eastern european language great but you cannot probably image how much time we spent finding out how to correctly send an e-mail with accented characters from Catalyst (in the end, we had to dump the Catalyst plugin) :-)

Thanks for you great work, guys! Switched from PHP to Catalyst and loving it so far! Just a bit tough to find good Perl devs here...
